holidays.name: Ides of March
holidays.description: Marking the date famously known as the day Julius Caesar was assassinated in 44 BC, the Ides of March is a day steeped in historical drama, political intrigue, and ominous omens. It's a quirky reminder to beware the Ides!
holidays.origin: Ancient Roman calendar, with the 'Ides' referring to the middle of the month; Shakespeare immortalized the date in his play Julius Caesar.
holidays.funFact: The phrase 'Beware the Ides of March' comes from a soothsayer's warning that Caesar ignored‚Äîleading to his downfall!
